pageInline.title: Jaime Hyland
pageInline.tagline: Full-stack developer — Django & Next.js with i18n
pageInline.description: I'm a full-stack developer with a background in languages and education who enjoys building clean, attractive and scalable web apps that inform, educate, increase productivity and improve quality of life.
pageInline.buttonLabel: Looking for a collaborator or developer?

techsSection.heading: Some of the technologies I work with

python.title: Python
python.description: I use Python mainly in Django coding, in Flask and for scripting.

javascript.title: JavaScript
javascript.description: JavaScript is the most commonly used programming language for creating website frontends together with HTML and CSS. It's used both to access and manipulate data and the DOM, and to modify HTML and CSS code.

typescript.title: TypeScript
typescript.description: TypeScript is a superset of JavaScript. It enforces stricter typing, provides autocomplete, IntelliSense, and smart hints, making it very useful for writing, debugging, and refactoring code. I use it pretty intensively together with Next.js and React when building and maintaining this site.

dart.title: Dart
dart.description: Used with Flutter for cross-platform mobile development, Dart is a modern, class-based language inspired by JavaScript, Java, and C#. It compiles to native code for fast, smooth apps on iOS and Android, or to JavaScript for the web, and offers strong typing and powerful async support. Its hot reload feature saves waiting-around time time, making the development experience faster and less frustrating.

java.title: Java Swing
java.description: Java Swing is a framework for building desktop graphical user interfaces. I used it on one occasion to create a simple desktop app to allow an admin to maintain data in a MySQL database. Earlier, I had to dabble in it to adapt complex UIs to support locales other than the original German.

cpp.title: C++
cpp.description: I first encountered C++ during a three-month course, where I became acquainted with some of its basic features. I gained exposure to its benefits as a high-performance development language offering fine-grained control over memory. Later, I dabbled in it while troubleshooting stubborn internationalization issues.

dotnet.title: Visual Basic .NET
dotnet.description: VB .NET is an object-oriented programming language developed by Microsoft, designed to run on the .NET framework. I used it primarily to manipulate the Passolo object model in efforts to automate localization of resources. I also used it to examine source-language and localized strings for consistency, ensuring the absence of prohibited substrings and unlocalizable concatenations.

html5.title: HTML5
html5.description: The standard markup language for creating and structuring content on the web.

css3.title: CSS3
css3.description: The style sheet language used to control the presentation, layout, and appearance of web content.

django.title: Django
django.description: Django is a high-level Python web framework that facilitates startlingly rapid development and clean, pragmatic design. I have used it both as a pure backend (with Next.js or Flutter on the frontend, PostgreSQL as the database, and implementing RESTful APIs to bridge the backend and frontend), and also across the full stack, creating applications all the way to the user interface with the help of React, Bootstrap, and other tools.

flask.title: Flask
flask.description: Flask is a lightweight Python web framework without any built-in ORM, admin panel, or templating system. I dabbled in it during hackathons to help create RESTful APIs.

react.title: React
react.description: React is a widely-used JavaScript library for building interactive user interfaces. It has a component-based architecture with reusable components and supports state management. I have mainly used it to create more or less complex modals, responsive buttons and similar controls.

nextjs.title: Next.js
nextjs.description: App Router, server actions, API routes.

bootstrap.title: Bootstrap
bootstrap.description: Rapid prototyping with prebuilt UI components.

postgresql.title: PostgreSQL
postgresql.description: Primary database for Django and analytics apps.

heroku.title: Heroku
heroku.description: Deployment of Django and Node.js apps.

nodejs.title: Node.js
nodejs.description: Node.js is a runtime for tools and servers that allows you to use JavaScript elsewhere than directly on a browser. Among other things, it allows you develop website backends coding JavaScript. It's worth noting that Node.js is the harness in which Next.js and many other web framworks do their thing. It's also an essential toolkit when building stuff within the React ecosystem.

educationSection.heading: Some of the places I've been doing my learning
educationSection.fasModalContent: FÁS was the Irish National Vocational Training Authority at the time I did my foundational training in IT there. It has since been replaced by <link>Solas</link>.
educationSection.trinityModalContent: I studied Philosophy (or "Mental and Moral Science", as the degree course is still called) at <link>Trinity College Dublin</link>. Back in ancient history (1984 to 1988), I did quite a lot of work there on philosophy of logic and mathematics.
educationSection.codeInstituteModalContent:
I completed an online <link>full-stack software development diploma</link> course at the excellent Dublin-based educator Code Institute from 2023 to the end of 2024.
The course put a particular emphasis on the Python language for the modern web, leveraging the Django and Bootstrap frameworks.
My specialized final portfolio project was an e-Commerce site, using Stripe as its online payment system.
educationSection.khanModalContent: <link>Khan Academy</link> is an excellent resource for IT training and Maths education. I've used it so far in self-training in Computer Science Theory, JavaScript programming, Statistics and Calculus.
educationSection.codefinityModalContent: <link>Codefinity</link> is yet another excellent resource for IT training. So far, I've been using it for a variety of learning materials, with a special emphasis on Python.
educationSection.brilliantModalContent: <link>Brilliant</link> is my go-to place when I want to take a short, but productive break. I've been using it so far mainly to revise my old school general maths, and to learn a little about electrical circuits, which has been a closed book to me all my life.
educationSection.kodekloudModalContent:
I've been using <link>KodeKloud</link> on and off to improve my as yet fairly primitive understanding of Linux.
It's an excellent provider of training — in DevOps in particular.
educationSection.leetcodeModalContent: I've been using <link>LeetCode</link> mainly to get a grip on some of the common questions that might come up for me when applying for a job as a full-stack web programmer.
educationSection.linkedinModalContent:
<link>LinkedIn Learning</link> provides a wide variety of courses on the whole gamut of professional disciplines that one may need to learn in the IT industry and elsewhere.
It is the product of LinkedIn's purchase of the famous IT training provider Lynda.com.
So far, I've used it mostly to get a grip on Dart/Flutter.
educationSection.freecodecampModalContent:
<link>freecodecamp</link> is my original provider of many of my basic skills on web development.
I've got enormous mileage out of its Certified Full Stack Developer Curriculum (though it's still in Beta testing at time of writing).
